title: Cat. 14  Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook, 1894/95
publication_title: Pissarro Paintings and Works on Paper at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook  
1894/95  
Oil on canvas; 73.5 × 92 cm (28 5/8 × 36 in.)  
Signed and dated: C. Pissarro 1895 (lower left, in brown-red paint)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, A Millennium Gift of the Sara Lee Corporation, 1999.364

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">This large, highly worked, and ambitious painting was probably completed in early 1895, the year Paul Cézanne’s bathers made their first appearance in Paris since 1877. They were shown in an enormous one-person exhibition held at Ambroise Vollard’s gallery in November and December, which Pissarro attended. Writing to his daughter-in-law Esther Bensusan-Pissarro in November 1895, the artist complained about his finances and described his struggle to sell works against the backdrop of what he believed was a successful showing for his friend, ending the passage with praise and excitement for Cézanne’s achievement:

I have not contributed to the household finances for two months now, but I have a renewed sense of hope. There is a significantly considerable exhibition of Cézanne’s works at Vollard’s right now. There are stunningly rendered still lifes, and some other unfinished works[,] but they are truly breathtaking in their primitive character and authenticity. I don’t think that many will fully appreciate what he has done.

Perhaps Pissarro’s hopefulness came from witnessing the accomplishment of Cézanne’s works despite his friend’s eighteen-year absence from the art scene. The success of the show must have been especially encouraging in light of his own series of bathers, which he began in early 1894. Pissarro already knew Cézanne’s early bathers, not only because he must have seen them when he worked with the painter in the 1870s, but also because he already owned at least two from the 1860s and 1870s. On the occasion of Cézanne’s 1895 solo show, Pissarro also traded one of his Louveciennes studies for two small works by Cézanne, one featuring bathers and one a self-portrait, attesting to Pissarro’s appreciation of his friend’s works and admiration of his aesthetic approach. As he said in a letter to his son Lucien,

Upon leaving Portier’s I thought of how rare it is to find real painters these days, who know how to juxtapose two colors . . . [ . . . ] I also thought about Cézanne’s exhibition, where there are exquisite works on display; still lifes with an unrivalled finish and some others which are very overworked and yet abandoned midway in their execution, and even more beautiful than all the rest. There are landscapes, nudes, unfinished portraits and yet they are truly extravagant, so artistic and so graceful . . . How, you ask?? Because the feeling is there!

Interestingly, Pissarro had a major influence on Cézanne’s decision to hold a one-person show, pushing his friend for several months and even offering to lend some of his Cézannes. Pissarro may have also seen this as an opportunity to test the waters for his own bathers works, as he had not yet exhibited any of his own nudes by the time Cézanne’s exhibition opened.

Pissarro began to study female bathers out of doors in a small series of paintings and prints completed in 1894. A smaller oil painting that might even be considered a study for the present work, The Foot Bath (fig. 14.1 [PDRS 1060]), is signed and dated 1894, like three other bather paintings [PDRS 1057, 1058, 1059], two etchings of female bathers, and one lithograph. They seem like summer pictures, but Pissarro was in Belgium for most of the summer and autumn of that year, far from landscapes like these along the Epte River, which flowed from his farm in Éragny to Monet’s in Giverny. But as Pissarro tended not to paint his figural pictures from life but rather constructed them from drawings, it was not necessary for him to actually witness the scenes. The largest of the three bather compositions (fig. 14.2 [PDRS 1057]) relates directly to two etchings that Pissarro printed on a press he acquired in January 1894. It seems that he painted the 1894 Bathers (fig. 14.2) by inserting all the figures portrayed in his etchings and drawing—including the woman immersed up to her shoulders in the background—into the new work’s composition (fig. 14.3, fig. 14.4, and fig. 14.5).

Indeed, in a letter written to his son Lucien on January 14, 1894, he reported that he was making etchings of female bathers. Two of these relate precisely to the painting and to at least one preparatory drawing in the Ashmolean Museum (fig. 14.6). It is likely pure coincidence that before Cézanne’s monographic exhibition opened at Vollard’s, Pissarro had already painted a large series of his own with two principal canvases: the present work and an equally large study of three nude female bathers completed in 1896 (Three Bathers Stepping Out of the Water [PDRS 1108]). Although it is tempting to read this series as a kind of pictorial homage to Cézanne, it is likely that even the latter canvas was begun before he saw the Cézanne exhibition. In short, Pissarro’s bathers seem to have been conceived independently of Cézanne and, in fact, evoke a range of artists from François Boucher to Jean-François Millet and Pierre-Auguste Renoir rather more than they do Cézanne. In the same January 1894 letter to Lucien, he also says that he is trying to paint new subjects and that “six or seven canvases are very advanced.” Tellingly, Pissarro also reports to his son that his wife is in Paris, subtly implying that it was possible for him to hire female models to pose in the nude without seeking her approval. Thus, what clearly seem to be “summer” pictures were, in all likelihood completed in the winter. Also, in a letter to Lucien dated January 15, 1896, before Pissarro left for his painting campaign in Rouen, he mentioned three works featuring bathers: “I’ve completed four size ten and fifteen canvases depicting Rosa. I’ve also finished my three size thirty canvases of nudes; with all that I still have in terms of older works, the total amount of figure paintings should amount to about fifteen.”

Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook and the c. 1894–95Footbath (fig. 14.6) possess deep art-historical roots. The subject can be found in countless biblical pictures from the Renaissance and Baroque periods, but the most compelling connections are with the eighteenth-century paintings of Boucher and Jean-Honoré Fragonard, who evoked similarly seductive rural women in superficially chaste but sexually charged scenes designed for male viewers (see fig. 14.7). The most frequently cited source for Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook is The Bather, an 1863 oil painting by Millet representing a young peasant woman tending geese (fig. 14.8). She has removed her clothes to wash in a calm river that is startlingly similar to the one in the Art Institute’s work. Millet’s painting was shown twice in 1886 and at a sale in Paris in 1892, but Pissarro’s letters, usually very detailed in this regard, do not indicate that he viewed it at any of those venues. Although it is possible that he saw a reproduction, this is unlikely. Other inspiration could have come from Renoir’s many female bathers of the later 1880s and early 1890s or, more likely, from Edgar Degas’s late investigations of the nude, with which Pissarro was intimately familiar.

It is tempting to relate Millet’s Bather to Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook, but it may be more persuasively connected to the nude cognate of this work by Pissarro, Bather (1895; fig. 14.9 [PDRS 1062]), with which it has more convincing, if undocumented, rhymes. The nude bather was painted on a smaller canvas, and no preparatory drawing for it survives. This makes it difficult to ascertain just how Pissarro transformed the clothed version into a nude, as he must have done because The Foot Bath (fig. 14.1) is clearly the instigator of the sequence. The poses, too, diverge enough so as not to be directly related. This may indicate, however, that Pissarro’s working process was gradual, and he found inspiration in his own works when creating his series, as his letters from 1894 suggest. In a January 1894 note to Lucien, the artist announced his plan to begin his bathers, and he often alluded to working on the same nudes throughout that year. By late November 1894 he described his careful finishing and incessant reworking of his bathers series, even detailing how he was still trying to perfect one work after eight months.

Since we know that the clothed bather was already in Dresden at an exhibition in February 1895 and that the nude had sold in October 1895, it is certain that the former painting was made late in 1894 or early in 1895, well before Pissarro’s departure for Belgium in June, and begun as early as the etchings of bathers created in the studio in January 1894. The large-scale colored chalk study with pastel highlights in the Ashmolean Museum (fig. 14.6) was most likely created after The Foot Bath (fig. 14.1), and seems to have been drawn from a local model who posed in Pissarro’s studio. Pissarro obviously studied the drawing as he worked on the painting, but there is no physical evidence that he transferred it from paper to canvas as his younger colleague Paul Gauguin often did. Furthermore, although the painting and the pastel are very similar, there are enough differences in the figure’s pose to rule out such a transfer. Rather, the drawing seems to have been a graphic exercise meant to facilitate the drawing on the canvas—undoubtedly made with the pastel, not the model herself, in front of him.

The rugged, physically varied surface and the numerous subtle changes to the figure and her clothing, indicated by the thick buildup of paint visible in details and in the X-ray (see fig. 14.10 and fig. 14.11), make it clear that Pissarro worked on the canvas over months. It undoubtedly pleased him, because he sent it to two exhibitions in Germany early in 1895, suggesting that he signed and dated it in January of that year. Hence, it is possible that the nude Bather (fig. 14.9) was also largely painted in 1894, because the two works may have been created at the same moment. Sadly, neither painting has had much traction in the Pissarro bibliography or in the many exhibitions of his oeuvre. This surely results from the fact that, for so many people who look at them, their 1895 date links them to Cézanne’s much more advanced paintings of bathers. Pissarro’s aims thus have been misunderstood in precisely the same ways that his early 1880s figure paintings were misunderstood by being linked to Millet’s. Indeed, his complex, layered working method and his stubborn refusal to develop his art in a linear manner meant that his output—particularly the figurative portion—was destined to be compared to the works of his peers and predecessors rather than to be assessed in its own right. Yet we must remember that the dealer Paul Durand-Ruel and the Pissarro family, in choosing a large group of his most successful paintings and works on silk and paper for his posthumous retrospective at Durand-Ruel, Paris, elected to include the present work. It was successful there, as it seems to have been purchased in connection with the exhibition.  
Richard R. Brettell

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Pissarro began with a contour sketch in dilute blue paint on a commercially primed, standard-size canvas with a white ground. The artist built up compositional elements within the sketched lines, leaving a thin, almost unpainted border along the edges of forms that is quite clear in the X-ray. There are changes to the figure’s hairstyle and the angle of her head, in addition to a number of changes to the volume, distribution, and position of the skirt. Throughout the painting process, the artist continually added more fabric to the front of the figure’s skirt, while reducing volume at the back and side. As a result, the figure’s legs became more covered with each successive alteration. In order to make changes to the composition, Pissarro executed a new contour sketch in thin blue paint directly over the earlier compositional choices before continuing; this is evident throughout the figure. The painting has a great deal of texture, as he used primarily soft brushes with thick, paste-like paint to drag layers of paint across the surface hitting only the high points of the underlying texture and exaggerating it. Near the end of the painting process, the artist dragged a stiffer brush across the soft paint in the foreground to create the illusion of the glassy surface of the brook. The work is currently unvarnished.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 14.12).

Signed and dated: C. Pissarro 1895 (lower left, in brown-red paint) (fig. 14.13, fig. 14.14).

Flax, commonly known as linen.

The original size of the canvas was approximately 72.5 × 92 cm, measuring from the original foldover. This probably corresponds to a no. 30 portrait (figure) standard size (92 × 73 cm), turned horizontally.

Plain weave. Average thread count (standard deviation) 26.1V (0.8) × 22.8H (0.7) threads/cm. The vertical threads were determined to correspond to the warp, and the horizontal threads were determined to correspond to the weft.

Light cusping on all sides corresponds to original tack holes, while stronger, primary cusping at the right and top is evidence of commercial preparation. The weft thread-count deviation map indicates a small area of more loosely woven canvas about 1 cm wide approximately one-third of the canvas’s height from the top (fig. 14.15).

Current stretching: The painting was lined in past treatment and its dimensions slightly increased on all sides.

Original stretching: Based on cusping visible in the X-ray, the original tacks were placed approximately 4.5–7 cm apart.

Current stretcher: The work is currently stretched in a five-member ICA spring stretcher with a vertical crossbar. Depth: 2.5 cm.

Previous stretcher: A pre-lining examination notes the work was stretched on a four-member mortise-and-key stretcher; it is unclear if that stretcher was original. Depth: Unknown.

Stamp  
Location: canvas verso, obscured by lining (transcribed in Conservation File)  
Method: stamp  
Content: [P. Contet / PARIS]

Not determined.

The ground is very smooth, filling much of the relatively fine canvas weave, and appears commercially applied and appears to be a single layer (fig. 14.16). The preparation extends to the edges of the tacking margins on the left and bottom edges, stopping short of the edges at top and right; the softness along the edges of the preparation on the latter two sides suggests application with a soft brush (see fig. 14.17).

The ground appears white, with no colored particles visible under stereomicroscopic examination (fig. 14.18). Visual examination of a cross section of the ground and canvas reveals traces of black, yellow-orange, and red particles.

XRF analysis indicates that the ground is composed of predominantly lead white with small amounts of iron oxides and calcium compounds, such as calcium carbonate and/or calcium sulfate. The binder is estimated to be oil.

The extent of underdrawing is not entirely clear due to the thickness of the paint layer, but microscopic examination indicates the figure was sketched in paint prior to execution.

Pissarro used thin blue paint to sketch the figure; some of this is left visible along the edges of forms (see fig. 14.19).

While there are no discernible differences between the sketched and painted compositions, most compositional changes to the figure in the painting stage were outlined in dilute blue paint directly over the previous forms before execution (see fig. 14.20). For specific compositional changes, see Paint Layer.

This painting is heavily and meticulously worked, and Pissarro made numerous small changes to the composition while slowly building up a thick impasto in a series of wet-in-wet campaigns. He began with a contour sketch and often strictly followed this guide, executing each compositional choice fully before making alterations. Each form is articulated within its blue outline, leaving a small margin of thin paint between the edges of forms that often exposes the underdrawing and is visible in the X-ray and transmitted-light images. The head and hair of the figure appear to be the most labored areas of the painting, appearing quite radio-opaque in the X-ray. The infrared image indicates changes to the back of the figure’s neck and her hairstyle; either her bun was originally slightly lower on her head or the style was looser and more elongated (see fig. 14.21). In the X-ray evidence can be seen of small changes in both the area of the bun and of the figure’s profile. Close examination of the painting’s surface reveals that the artist reduced the size and volume of the figure’s hair at the back by bringing in additional background paint to hem it in (see fig. 14.22). The X-ray also reveals that the figure’s nose was slightly higher originally and displayed a different profile. Under the microscope, flesh tones from the original nose are still visible under the grass, as is the artist’s second underdrawing directly on top of it (fig. 14.23).

Pissarro also made numerous changes to the figure’s skirt, possibly trying multiple versions before settling on the visible arrangement. The X-ray indicates that the figure’s dress was first slightly bunched up behind her, spreading further onto the grass, rather than neatly tucked underneath her as in the present composition. Originally the right edge of the skirt was more voluminous; its browns, purples, and blues can be seen between the green dabs of paint articulating the grass. As he did in the figure’s hair, here the artist amended the skirt by covering the excess volume with additional background paint (see fig. 14.24). Initially the skirt was arranged with a greater volume of fabric on the side, while the figure’s legs were left more exposed. Although the amount of skirt behind and beside the figure may have been greater at the outset, the amount of fabric covering her legs was much less. Combining information from various technical images, it appears that the artist moved the skirt three or four different times, covering more and more of the leg down to the knee. Raking light and X-ray examinations indicate that at one time the skirt may have reached above the cuff of the figure’s sleeve, almost as high as her elbow, draping across her lap and exposing much of her left leg. If so, the skirt would have stopped at what is now the first of many light-colored folds above the knee (see fig. 14.25). Small voids in the upper paint layers in this area reveal the initial flesh tones from this first configuration (see fig. 14.26). Over time, the artist added folds in additional pale colors to cover the figure’s legs first; next he added volume along the figure’s left side, as seen in transmitted infrared and raking light; then he incorporated additional pinks and mauve tones across the lap (see the reflected and transmitted infrared images) that connect to a dark purple fold at the right; and finally he added the lightest tones across the thigh and to the right of the figure.

The painting was meticulously executed with relatively small brushes and a thick, paste-like paint consistency. Each layer was dragged over the underlying texture, catching the high points and reinforcing the texture, resulting in an almost pebbly surface (see fig. 14.27). In the foreground, Pissarro dragged a dry brush across the still-soft paint to create the horizontal highlights and indicate the movement and reflective qualities of the water (see fig. 14.28).

Relatively fine, soft-bristle brushes with strokes up to 0.5 cm.

XRF analysis suggests the presence of the following pigments: lead white; vermilion; iron oxide red, yellow, and/or brown; chrome yellow; cobalt blue, emerald green; and possibly viridian. Visual observation and stereomicroscopic examination suggest the presence of red lake (fig. 14.29) and black (fig. 14.30).

Oil (estimated).

The work is currently unvarnished, with residues of natural-resin varnish in the depressions of the paint layer and around areas of impasto.

In 1981 the painting was examined while in the collection of its previous owner, where it was noted to be unlined, stretched on a four-member mortise-and-key stretcher with slightly warped members, and a yellow, probably natural-resin varnish. The work was subsequently cleaned, wax-resin lined, stretched on a redwood spring stretcher of slightly larger dimensions, and given a synthetic Soluvar varnish. In 2000, upon acquisition by the Art Institute, the painting was noted to have a stable wax-resin lining and a five-member ICA spring stretcher. The restretched dimensions were noted as slightly larger than the original, and pinholes were present in the corners of the canvas. Some flattening of the impasto, probably as a result of the lining, and a glossy, probably synthetic varnish were also documented. The painting was treated shortly after this examination, in 2001; the varnish was removed and the work received minor retouching around the edges.

The painting is in very good condition, wax-resin lined, planar, and with few cracks or losses. It is unvarnished, with residues of discolored natural resin in the interstices and depressions of the paint film, and has a margin of retouching around the edges, especially along the top. Old pinholes in three corners have been filled and inpainted.  
Kelly Keegan

Current frame: The frame is not original to the painting. It is an American, c. 1980 stylization of a Louis XIII or Louis XIV transitional frame, cushion framed with projecting fanned lambrequin and flower corners, running-leaf sight molding, and an independent fillet liner. The frame has water and oil gilding over red bole on gesso. The gilding is heavily rubbed on the ornament and rails and toned overall. The carved basswood moldings are mitered and nailed, and glued to a back frame. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, is ovolo with half patera; cove side; cushion face with projecting fanned lambrequin and flower corners on a quadrillage bed, connected by plain reposes; sanded frieze; ovolo sight molding with running-leaf ornament on a straight-lined bed; and an independent fillet liner (fig. 14.31).

Previous frame (installed by 1970): The work was previously housed in what appears to have been a reproduction of a Louis XV reverse ogee frame with swept sides, anthemia corner and shell center cartouches connected by foliate rocaille ornament, and an independent linen-covered liner. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, was ovolo with dentil; scotia side; reverse ogee face with projecting and pierced anthemia corner and shell center cartouches on diamond beds, connected by swept scroll sides with foliate rocaille ornament on the face; sanded frieze; ogee sight molding; and an independent fillet liner (fig. 14.32).  
Kirk Vuillemot

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook (PV 903; PDRS 1061) corresponds to the Pissarro catalogues raisonnés: PV, vol. 1, p. 206, cat. 903; vol. 2, pl. 183, cat. 903; and PDRS, vol 3, p. 678, cat. 1061 (ill.). The Art Institute currently uses a title that is based on the one used by the artist when describing the Art Institute’s painting to his son Lucien in a letter dated December 14, 1894, and on research conducted for the 2008 exhibition The Impressionists: Master Paintings from the Art Institute of Chicago. For the letter see Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), p. 521 (letter 1080).

The painting was dated 1894/95 based on research conducted for the 2008 exhibition The Impressionists: Master Paintings from the Art Institute of Chicago. This date includes the inscribed date of 1895 and indicates that Pissarro may have begun the painting in the latter part of 1894, which is suggested by letters from the artist to his son Lucien. See Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), pp. 513 (letter 1073), 521 (letter 1080).

John Rewald, Cézanne, A Biography (Abrams, 1986), pp. 189, 207–08, 269. For Pissarro’s attending Cézanne’s solo show in 1895, see also Camille Pissarro to Esther Bensusan-Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 13, 1895, and Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 19, 1895, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 4, 1895–1898 (Valhermeil, 1989), pp. 112–16. At the third Impressionist exhibition in 1877, Cézanne showed one work depicting bathers, which, according to Ruth Berson, has not been identified with certainty. See Ruth Berson, ed., The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 2, Exhibited Works (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 71. After showing with the Impressionists in 1874 and 1877, Cézanne’s next exhibition was a monographic one at Ambroise Vollard’s gallery, which ran from November to December 1895.

“À la maison, je n’ai rien donné depuis deux mois, cependant j’ai un peu d’espoir. Chez Vollard il y a une exposition de Cézanne très complète. Des natures mortes d’un fini étonnant, des choses inachevées, mais vraiment extraordinaires de sauvagerie et de caratère, je crois que ce sera peu compris.” Camille Pissarro to Esther Bensusan-Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 13, 1895, and Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 19, 1895, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 4, 1895–1898 (Valhermeil, 1989), p. 113. All excerpts from Pissarro’s letters in this entry were translated by Elpida Vouitsis, a doctoral candidate at the University of Texas, Dallas. My thanks to Vouitsis for translating all of the letters cited in this entry.

PDRS, vol. 1, p. 261. For Pissarro’s exchange of one of his poorer Louveciennes studies for one of Cézanne’s works featuring bathers and a self-portrait, see Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 19, 1895, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 4, 1895–1898 (Valhermeil, 1989), pp. 115–16.

“En sortant de chez Portier je me faisais cette réflexion: combien il est rare de trouver de vrais peintres, qui sachent mettre en accord deux tons . . . [. . .] Je pensais aussi à l’exposition de Cézanne où il y a des choses exquises, des Natures mortes d’un achevé irréproachable, d’autres très travaillées et cependant laissées en plan, [cependant] encore plus belles que les autres, des paysages, des nus, des têtes inachevées et cependant vraiment grandioses, et si peintre, si souples . . . pourquoi?? La sensation y est!” (ellipses in the original). Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 21, 1895, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg,ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 4, 1895–1898 (Valhermeil, 1989), p. 119.

Camille Pissarro to Esther Bensusan-Pissarro, Paris, Nov. 13, 1895, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 4, 1895–1898 (Valhermeil, 1989), p. 114, n 2.

For Pissarro’s works featuring nude bathers executed between 1894 and 1896, see PDRS, vol. 3, pp. 675–76, 678–79, 696–700. The only work featuring nude bathers that was exhibited in the late nineteenth century was PDRS 1108, Three Bathers Stepping Out of the Water (1896). It was shown for the first time at Pissarro’s solo show in 1896 at Durand-Ruel, Paris, which ran from April 15 to May 9, 1896. See also PDRS, vol. 1, p. 364. Of Pissarro’s entire bathers series (both his dressed figures and nudes), only the Art Institute’s painting was exhibited before Cézanne’s monographic exhibition took place; it appeared in Dresden and Berlin in the early months of 1895.

For the etchings see PDRS, vol. 3, p. 675. For the lithograph see PDRS, vol. 3, p. 679. There also exist two other versions: the pencil, ink, and wash The Two Bathers (Ashmolean Museum Oxford; see PDRS vol. 3, p. 675) and the gouache Peasant Crossing a Brook (c. 1894; Wildenstein Institute Archives, Paris; see PDRS, vol. 3, p. 676). Pissarro also created a colored-chalk version with pastel highlights entitled The Foot Bath, which shows a figure that is almost exactly the same as that in the Art Institute’s 1895 painting.

For these works see PDRS, vol. 3, p. 675; and Richard Brettell and Christopher Lloyd, A Catalogue of the Drawings by Camille Pissarro in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (Clarendon, 1980), cat. 294. There also exists a charcoal preparatory drawing by Pissarro of the nude woman bending forward without any other compositional elements (1894/95; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford). It measures 288 × 223 mm. See Richard Brettell and Christopher Lloyd, A Catalogue of the Drawings by Camille Pissarro in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (Clarendon, 1980), cat. 257, p. 185.

Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Éragny, Jan. 14, 1894, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), pp. 418–19.

Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Éragny, Jan. 14, 1894, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), pp. 418–19.

“J’ai terminé quatre toiles de dix et quinze d’après la Rosa, j’ai aussi terminé mes trois toiles de trente, nus; avec ce que j’ai d’anciennes choses, cela me fera une quinzaine de tableaux de figures.” Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Éragny, Jan. 15, 1896, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 4, 1895–1898 (Valhermeil, 1989), p. 149. See PDRS 1061, 1108, vol. 3, pp. 678, 699. The no. 30 portrait standard-size canvas measured 92 × 73 cm. Two of Pissarro’s paintings featuring bathers from 1895 and 1896 correspond to these dimensions: the Art Institute’s Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook (73.5 × 92 cm) and a later work, Three Bathers Stepping out of the Water (1896; PDRS 1108; 74 × 92 cm). None of the remaining works featuring bathers listed in PDRS correspond to the dimensions of this third painting mentioned in Pissarro’s January 1896 letter to Lucien; all of the remaining bathers created between 1894 and 1896 that are listed are smaller.

Millet’s painting was exhibited in conjunction with the John Saulnier estate sales in 1886 and 1892. Both times, the work was shown to the public the day before the sale took place. When the work failed to sell after Saulnier’s death in 1886, it—along with eleven other paintings—was exhibited in March 1892 at the Sedelmeyer Gallery in Paris, where it finally sold. See Vente après décès: Collection de vente John Saulnier de Bordeaux; tableaux modernes de premier ordre; Vente Hôtel Drouot, le samedi 5 juin, 1886 (Haro Frères, 1886); and Collection John Saulnier de Bordeaux: 12 tableaux modernes de premier ordre; Galerie Sedelmeyer, le vendredi 25 mars, 1892 (P. Chevalier, 1892).

It seems that Millet’s painting was only reproduced in conjunction with two estate sales, in 1886 and 1892, perhaps not easily accessible to Pissarro. The first reproduction appeared in an estate sale catalogue after the death of the painting’s owner, John Saulnier (lot 64, estimated at 29,100 francs). It did not sell. In 1892 at the Sedelmeyer gallery in Paris, the painting sold for 48,000 francs to one Mr. Engel. For this sale see La Chronique des beaux-arts et de la curiosité: supplément de la Gazette des Beaux-Arts, no. 14 (Apr. 2, 1892). Millet’s painting was reproduced in Vente après décès, Collection de vente John Saulnier de Bordeaux: tableaux modernes de premier ordre; Vente Hôtel Drouot, le samedi 5 juin, 1886 (Haro Frères, 1886), lot 64, p. 44. In each sale catalogue, the painting’s 1886 and 1892 sale prices are penciled in next to the catalogue entry. See also Collection John Saulnier de Bordeaux, 12 tableaux modernes de premier ordre: Galerie Sedelmeyer, le vendredi 25 mars, 1892 (P. Chevalier, 1892), lot 10, p. 14. The Art Institute sold the 1892 Saulnier sale catalogue that year. The painting, however, never appeared in Millet’s 1875 estate sale catalogue because it was purchased directly from the artist by his Belgian dealers, Ennemond Blanc and Arthur Stevens, in the early 1860s. See Catalogue de la vente qui aura lieu par suite du décès de Jean-François Millet, à l’hôtel Drouot les lundi 10 et mardi 11 mai, 1875 à deux heures (Alcan-Lévy, 1875). For Millet’s business relationship with Blanc and Stevens, who commissioned works directly from the artist for three years (1860–63), see Alexandra R. Murphy, Jean-François Millet: Drawn into the Light (Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, 1999), p. 32. The contract stipulated that Millet would produce twenty-five paintings in return for a monthly stipend over a period of three years. See also “Millets in the Art Institute,” Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 43, 7 (Oct. 1924), pp. 87–88, for Millet’s three-year business deal with Blanc and Stevens.

For Degas’s series of nudes exhibited at the last Impressionist exhibition in 1886, see Ruth Berson, ed., The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 2, Exhibited Works (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco/University od Washington Press, 1996), pp. 240–41, 258–59.

In a letter dated November 5, 1894, to his son Lucien from Éragny, Pissarro opened with his announcement of a completed gouache entitled Gardeuse d’oies. See published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), p. 503. This work is PV 1475; see also PV vol. 1, p. 285. Despite the similarity of their titles, Pissarro’s gouache bears no compositional resemblance to Millet’s painting Goose Girl. See also PDRS 1061, 1062, vol. 3, p. 678. The precise relationship between the nude and the clothed variants of the same composition is difficult to ascertain without a comparable comprehensive technical investigation of the Metropolitan’s picture.

For Pissarro’s letters from 1894 see Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), pp. 418–527. The painting worked on by Pissarro for over eight months is Peasant Girl Fording a Brook (PDRS 1059). Pissarro mentioned still working on this painting in two letters to his son Lucien, one from Paris dated November 22 and another from Éragny dated November 30, 1894, published in Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894, pp. 513, 516. In the second letter, Pissarro complained that he had made many alterations to the painting but that he was still not happy with it despite having started it the previous winter. Pissarro also made a gouache version of this work (Peasant Girl Fording a Brook; PDRS 1059) in circa 1894. In the November 22, 1894, letter to his son Lucien, when describing his obsessive reworking of this painting for most of the year, Pissarro also mentions working simultaneously on the Art Institute’s painting. When comparing these works, including the Indianapolis and Metropolitan paintings (PDRS 1059–62), it becomes clear that one idea may have led to another, as the bathers in all of them have their feet immersed in shallow pools of water. Aside from the nude version at the Metropolitan, the figures in the other works are all wearing full skirts with clearly discernible slips, demonstrating Pissarro’s gradual working process on his bathers series.

PDRS, vol. 3, p. 678; see also PDRS, vol. 1, p. 364, for its exhibition history. For the provenance of the Metropolitan’s picture see PDRS, vol. 3, pp. 678–79. The Metropolitan’s picture was sold by Pissarro in Paris to Tadamasa Hayashi in Tokyo through Alphonse Portier, on October 20, 1895, but only exhibited for the first time at the Metropolitan March 10–November 2, 1930. See Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Éragny, October 25, 1894, and Paris, November 22, 1894, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), pp. 498–99, 513. In the letter dated October 1894 Pissarro alludes to his series of nudes of “size 30 canvases” and states that they were taking up all of his time. According to Bailly-Herzberg’s note, the Art Institute’s painting, although dated 1895, was surely one of the works in the bathers series preoccupying Pissarro in 1894, as it is the only no. 30 portrait standard-size canvas featuring bathers from this period. In the November letter Pissarro seems to allude once again to the Art Institute’s painting, mentioning a Little Peasant on a no. 30 standard-size canvas. He says it is coming along but not quite finished, still lacking a certain something, but that it would soon be finished with the right inspiration. This implies that Pissarro may have been working on the painting throughout the year and in conjunction with other works featuring bathers. By mid-December 1894 Pissarro announced to his son Lucien that he was already planning on sending four or five paintings to Dresden and had tentatively decided which four to send (the list included the Art Institute’s picture), unless he changed his mind at the last minute, which indicates that Pissarro may still have been adding final touches to the work in early 1895. See Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Éragny, Dec. 14, 1894, published in Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894, p. 521.

See Richard Brettell and Christopher Lloyd, A Catalogue of the Drawings by Camille Pissarro in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (Clarendon, 1980), no. 259, p. 186. Interestingly, this preparatory chalk and pastel study is bigger than the Indianapolis Foot Bath of 1894 but smaller than the Art Institute’s of 1895.

See fig. 14.9 and the figure studies in Richard Brettell and Christopher Lloyd, A Catalogue of the Drawings by Camille Pissarro in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (Clarendon, 1980), pp. 185-86, cat. 257, 259. The chalk-and-pastel preparatory study (fig. 14.6, cat. 259)—due to its large size when compared with the other figure study by Pissarro (cat. 257)—may have been used by the artist in a way similar to his large preparatory drawing for the Art Institute’s painting Young Peasant Having Her Coffee of 1881 (cat. 10). The Art Institute also owns the drawing, only a few centimeters smaller than its painted cognate (cat. 9).

For the painting’s appearances in Germany, see PDRS, vol. 1, p. 364. The Art Institute’s painting was exhibited in Dresden at the Ernst Arnold Gallery from an unknown date in February to March 2, 1895, and again in Berlin at the gallery of Fritz Gurlitt from March 21 to April 15, 1895. See Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Éragny, Oct. 25, 1894, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 3, 1891–1894 (Valhermeil, 1988), p. 498–99. In this letter Pissarro described to his son his preoccupation with the series of nudes that he had already started that year. In the first note to this letter Bailly-Herzberg identifies the Art Institute’s painting as the “canvas size 30” mentioned by Pissarro, dated 1895 but started in 1894. She also identified the Metropolitan’s picture as another one of the works in his series of nudes begun in 1894, indicating a working relationship between the Art Institute’s bather and its nude cognate.

For Cézanne’s late bathers, see Mary Louise Krumrine, Paul Cézanne: The Bathers (Abrams, 1989), pp. 167–205.

For some of the reviews of Pissarro’s works from the seventh Impressionist exhibition in 1882, which linked the artist almost exclusively with the art of Millet, see the entry on Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (cat. 10), which translates many of the critics’ comments.

The Art Institute’s painting was posthumously exhibited along with 131 other works at Durand-Ruel, Paris, April 7–30, 1904, only a few months after the artist’s death. See PDRS, vol. 1, p. 366.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the painting may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. The jagged line icon brings up a list of available annotations, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the painting’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, UV, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the painting as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

Stereomicroscopic examination, in conjunction with XRF, suggests the signature is a complex mixture containing iron oxide brown and yellow and vermilion. The presence of iron and mercury was confirmed with XRF. See Federica Pozzi, “Psro\_WBathingBrook\_1999\_364\_XRF\_Results,” Nov. 15, 2012, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

Flax was confirmed by microscopic cross-sectional fiber identification; see Inge Fiedler, microanalysis results summary, May 5, 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

Original dimensions were determined by approximating foldover edges based on creases and old tack holes. Small discrepancies between the current measurements and standard sizes may be a result of this approximation. See the chart of standard sizes available from Bourgeois Aîné in 1888, reproduced in David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art in the Making: Impressionism (National Gallery, London/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 46, fig. 31.

Thread count and weave information were determined by Thread Count Automation Software. See Don H. Johnson and Robert G. Erdmann, “Thread Count Report Woman Bathing her Feet in a Brook, 1895 (PS1061/1999.364),” Dec. 2012.

The ground layer along these two sides only partially covers the tacking margins, leaving a small margin of unprimed canvas on the verso. These unprimed margins, in conjunction with the heavy cusping, probably indicate that this section of canvas came from a corner of a larger roll that had been commercially prepared. For a discussion of commercial canvas preparation, see David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art in the Making: Impressionism, exh. cat. (National Gallery/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 46; and Iris Schaefer, Caroline von Saint-George, and Katja Lewerentz, Painting Light: The Hidden Techniques of the Impressionists, exh. cat. (Skira, 2008), p. 52.

Observation by Don Johnson. See Don H. Johnson and Robert G. Erdmann, “Thread Count Report Woman Bathing her Feet in a Brook, 1895 (PS1061/1999.364),” Dec. 2012.

Despite this documentation, faint stretcher-bar cracks suggest the painting was for some time stretched on a five-member stretcher with a vertical crossbar. See Barry Bauman, “Examination Report: Woman Washing Her Legs by Camille Pissarro, 1980.3,” Sept. 1980, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

While not currently visible in transmitted-light or transmitted-infrared, the painting was noted to have a color merchant’s stamp that reads P. Contet. Paris on the verso prior to lining in 1981. P. Contet, formerly Latouche, was located at 34, rue Lafayette. See Stéphanie Constantin, “The Barbizon Painters: A Guide to Their Suppliers,” Studies in Conservation 46 (2001), p. 64. This stamp was also found on Pissarro’s Haymaking in Éragny (1892; cat. 12) and The Place du Havre, Paris (1893; cat. 13). See Stéphanie Constantin, “The Barbizon Painters: A Guide to Their Suppliers,” Studies in Conservation 46 (2001), p. 64; see also Barry Bauman, “Examination Report: Woman Washing Her Legs by Camille Pissarro, 1980.3,” Sept. 1980, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

Although glue-based sizing layers are common in commercial preparation, no such layer was visible in stereomicroscopic examination of the painting. In addition, a thinly applied sizing layer could have been absorbed by the canvas and may not be visible under the current circumstances. Cross-sectional analysis would be needed to confirm the presence of a sizing layer.

Visual analysis of cross sections suggests the ground is a single layer. See Inge Fiedler, microanalysis results summary, May 5, 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

Visual analysis of cross sections verified the presence of a white ground layer with traces of black, yellow-orange, and red particles visible in the matrix. XRF analysis was carried out in air. XRF does not detect organic pigments (including carbon blacks), if present. Further analysis would be needed to confirm the presence and specific type of black. See Inge Fiedler, microanalysis results summary, May 5, 2015; and Federica Pozzi, “Psro\_WBathingBrook\_1999\_364\_XRF\_Results,” Nov. 15, 2012, both on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

XRF analysis was carried out in air. XRF does not detect organic pigments, if present, and has low sensitivity for elements like silicon, aluminum, and phosphorus. For more detailed results and conditions used, see Federica Pozzi, “Psro\_WBathingBrook\_1999\_364\_XRF\_Results,” Nov. 15, 2012, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

The binding medium was not analyzed. The estimation of an oil medium is based on visual examination, as well as on knowledge of Pissarro’s technique and published analyses of Pissarro’s paintings. See Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), p. 3.

Small holes, extant in three corners and visible in the X-ray but now partially filled and inpainted, may indicate the use of spacers, or taquets bois, between painting campaigns. Possible evidence of these spacers is also seen on Pissarro’s Rabbit Warren at Pontoise, Snow (1879; cat. 8), Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (1881; cat. 10), Woman and Child at the Well (1882; cat. 11), and The Place du Havre, Paris (1893; cat. 13). For a discussion of taquets bois, see Iris Schaefer, Caroline von Saint-George, and Katja Lewerentz, Painting Light: The Hidden Techniques of the Impressionists (Skira, 2008), pp. 92–93. Similar pinholes were also found on Pissarro’s The Quays at Rouen (1883; Courtauld Institute, London); see Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), p. 5.

An example of this longer, looser hairstyle may be seen in a related painting from the previous year, Young Woman Washing Her Feet in a Brook (1894; Indianapolis Museum of Art; fig. 14.1 [PDRS 1060]).

While not as voluminous, the original configuration of the skirt, with excess fabric behind the figure and the skirt pulled up well above her knee, is very similar to two other versions of the same subject, the oil-on-canvas The Foot Bath (1894; Indianapolis Museum of Art; fig. 14.1) and the monotype A Young Woman Washing Her Feet at the Edge of a Stream (c. 1894–95; Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York; fig. 14.9 [PDRS 1060]).

The height of the skirt was similar to that seen in the related colord-chalk-and-pastel drawing Study of a Young Woman Bathing Her Legs (1895; Ashmolean Museum). The angle of the figure’s back, the tucked-under skirt behind her, the slightly bent arms, and the three-quarter-length sleeves also very closely recall this drawing (see fig. 14.6).

XRF analysis was carried out in air. XRF does not detect organic pigments (including lake pigments and carbon blacks), if present, and has low sensitivity for elements like silicon and sodium (components of ultramarine blue). Analysis was carried out on selected areas and may not include all pigments present in the painting. For more detailed results and conditions used, see Federica Pozzi, “Psro\_WBathingBrook\_1999\_364\_XRF\_Results,” Nov. 15, 2012, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

The binding medium was not analyzed. The estimation of an oil medium is based on visual examination, as well as on knowledge of Pissarro’s technique and published analyses of Pissarro’s paintings. See Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), pp. 1–16; and David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art In the Making: Impressionism (National Gallery, London/Yale University Press, 1990), pp. 72–75.

By the early 1880s Pissarro appears to have been very much against varnishing, preferring to exhibit works under glass, as in the seventh Impressionist exhibition in 1882. Some works, such as The Village of Éragny (1885; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford) feature a typed note from Pissarro’s daughter-in-law Esther expressing both Lucien and Camille’s general distaste for varnish. On the verso of Landscape at Chaponval (1880; Musée d’Orsay, Paris), the artist wrote, “please do not varnish this picture / C. Pissarro”. For discussion of Pissarro’s varnishing practices see Michael Swicklick, “French Painting and the Use of Varnish, 1750–1900,” Conservation Research: Studies in the History of Art 41, 2 (1993), pp. 168–69. For further discussion and a reproduction of Esther Pissarro’s typed note, see Anthea Callen, “The Unvarnished Truth: Mattness, ‘Primitivism,’ and Modernity in French Painting, c. 1870–1907,” Burlington Magazine 135, 1100 (Nov. 1994), pp. 739–40.
